title: 105_hr1511
content: The "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" highlights the significant increase in tuition costs at public colleges and universities, outpacing household income and consumer goods prices. Concerns about college affordability have reached a 30-year high, making college education one of the most expensive investments for American families. The Act establishes the "National Commission on the Cost of Higher Education" to address these issues. The "National Commission on the Cost of Higher Education" consists of 7 members appointed by various leaders and the Secretary of Education. Each member must have expertise in higher education finance, Federal financial aid programs, education economics research, higher education administration, or business efficiency. The Commission elects a Chairman and Vice Chairperson to lead its efforts. In the absence of the Chairperson, the Vice Chairperson assumes duties. A majority of Commission members constitute a quorum. Appointments must be made within 30 days. If not, designated officers can make appointments on behalf of leaders. Members of the Commission are entitled to one vote each, vacancies do not affect its powers and are filled as per original appointment, no additional pay is given, and initial meeting must occur within 40 days of enactment. SEC. 4. FUNCTIONS OF COMMISSION. The Commission will study and make recommendations on the increase in tuition, methods to reduce tuition, trends in administrative costs, faculty workload and remuneration, faculty-to-student ratios, construction and renovation of facilities, and impact on tuition. The Commission will study the impact of trends on tuition, financial aid affecting tuition increases, laws contributing to tuition hikes, data distribution on tuition trends, student financial aid's role in increased tuition, and other relevant topics. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress within 120 days of its first meeting, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for administrative and legislative action. Recommendations require a majority vote of the Commission members present and voting. The Commission has powers to submit a final report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations within 120 days of its first meeting. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, adopt rules and regulations, and request information from federal agencies for the purpose of carrying out the Act. The Commission can request facilities, services, and personnel from Federal agencies to assist in carrying out its duties under the Act. It can also use the United States mails and enter into contracts for research purposes. Staffing rules and regulations apply. The Chairperson of the Commission has the power to appoint an Executive Director and additional staff without following certain appointment regulations, at rates not exceeding the maximum rate for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission's expenses are authorized up to $650,000, with funds remaining available until expended or one year after the Commission's termination. The Commission will cease to exist 60 days after submitting its final report as required.
